claim: If you swallow gum, nothing will happen to you.

supporting.text: Gum is indigestible and passes through the digestive system intact, so swallowing it does not cause harm.

attacks.text: Gum is indigestible and passes through the digestive system intact, so swallowing it does not cause harm.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and typically require swallowing very large quantities over a short period.
Some people may experience mild digestive discomfort or nausea after swallowing gum.
Digestive discomfort from swallowing gum is usually temporary and not medically significant.

supporting.text: Swallowing gum occasionally is harmless, as it is excreted in feces without being absorbed by the body.

attacks.text: Swallowing gum occasionally is harmless, as it is excreted in feces without being absorbed by the body.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and require swallowing very large quantities.
Some people may experience mild digestive discomfort after swallowing gum.
Digestive discomfort from gum is temporary and not medically significant.

supporting.text: Medical consensus states that swallowing small amounts of gum poses no health risks to most individuals.

attacks.text: Medical consensus states that swallowing small amounts of gum poses no health risks to most individuals.
Swallowing large amounts of gum can lead to intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and require ingestion of very large quantities.
Some individuals may have allergic reactions to ingredients in chewing gum.
Allergic reactions to gum ingredients are well-documented and most people are aware of their allergies.

supporting.text: Gum does not stick to the intestines or stomach, contrary to common myths, so swallowing it is not dangerous.

attacks.text: Gum does not stick to the intestines or stomach, contrary to common myths, so swallowing it is not dangerous.
While gum does not stick to intestines, swallowing large quantities can cause intestinal blockages, especially in children.
Intestinal blockages from gum are extremely rare and typically require swallowing very large amounts over a short period.
Gum contains artificial sweeteners and chemicals that may cause digestive discomfort or allergic reactions in some individuals.
The digestive system processes most artificial sweeteners in gum without issue, and allergic reactions are uncommon.

supporting.text: While gum is not digested, it does not block the digestive tract unless consumed in extremely large quantities.

attacks.text: While gum is not digested, it does not block the digestive tract unless consumed in extremely large quantities.
Even small amounts of gum can cause blockages in individuals with pre-existing digestive conditions.
Such cases are extremely rare and not representative of the general population.
Swallowing gum can lead to discomfort or minor digestive issues even if it doesn't cause a full blockage.
These minor issues are temporary and do not pose any significant health risk.
